briefOverview: Isaiah prophesies of a future era when the Lord’s house is exalted and nations seek God’s instruction, followed by warnings that pride and idolatry will be humbled in the day of the Lord. The chapter calls the house of Jacob to walk in the Lord’s light and to stop trusting in human power and idols.
summary: Isaiah foresees the “last days” when the mountain of the Lord’s house is established, nations flow to it for teaching, and global peace replaces warfare as God judges among the nations. He invites the house of Jacob to walk in the Lord’s light but rebukes them for adopting foreign divination, accumulating wealth and military power, and filling the land with idols. The text announces a coming day of the Lord in which human pride is brought low and the Lord alone is exalted. Idols will be abolished, and people will seek refuge in rocks and caves in fear of divine majesty when God shakes the earth. The chapter ends with the admonition to cease trusting in mortal man.
externalContext: This chapter closely parallels Isaiah 2 (8th century BCE), delivered in the context of Judah and Jerusalem amid rising Assyrian pressure and ongoing concerns about idolatry and international alliances. “The mountain of the Lord’s house” originally evokes the Jerusalem temple mount, a symbol of divine rule and instruction. References to cedars of Lebanon, oaks of Bashan, and ships of Tarshish reflect markers of wealth, prestige, and far-reaching trade prominent in the ancient Near East. In the Book of Mormon, Nephi quotes extended portions of Isaiah to instruct his people, framing Isaiah’s prophecies as relevant to their future as well as to Israel’s. The “day of the Lord” is a standard prophetic motif signifying decisive divine intervention for judgment and purification.
externalReferences: The vision of nations streaming to the Lord’s house and “swords into plowshares” parallels Micah 4:1–3 and Isaiah 2:2–4. The imagery of people hiding in caves from the terror of the Lord echoes Revelation 6:15–17. The broader theme of the “day of the Lord” and earth-shaking judgment aligns with passages like Joel 2:1–11 and Zephaniah 1:14–18. The casting away of idols resonates with Isaiah 31:7, which calls for rejecting silver and gold idols.

sectionTitles.title: Day of the Lord Humbles All

practicalQuestions: In what ways might I rely on wealth, technology, or status as functional “idols,” and how can I tangibly set them aside to walk in the Lord’s light?
Where do I look for guidance—human voices and trends, or God’s instruction—and how can I better center my life on divine teaching?
How can I become a peacemaker in my family and community, embodying the vision of swords turned into plowshares?
What practices help cultivate humility so that God, not human pride, is exalted in my decisions?
How might I prepare spiritually for God’s searching judgment by repenting of habits that distance me from Him?
uncertainAreas: The precise referent of “replenished from the east,” “children of strangers,” and “pleasant pictures” is culturally and linguistically debated; these likely critique foreign-influenced practices, luxury, or cultic arts, but specifics are unclear. The timing and scope of “the last days” and “day of the Lord” are ambiguous—whether primarily near-term for Isaiah’s audience, eschatological, or both. The mention of “ships of Tarshish” may denote long-distance trade broadly, but the exact geography and nuance remain debated. The force of v. 9 (“forgive him not”) is difficult—whether a rhetorical denunciation or a prophetic declaration of judgment—and translation nuances may affect its interpretation.
